Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Medium: Collaborative Research: Non-Intrusive Multi-Patient Fall-Risk Monitoring in Health Care Facilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings together four investigators who identified an opportunity to bridge their disparate fields (gait analysis, body sensor networks, low power RF circuits, and gerontology) in order to address an extremely important health care problem of fall prevention. Their combined expertise addresses the following scientific objectives: (1) explore on-node signal processing and low power RF transceivers to balance energy consumption and mobility analysis fidelity in wireless on-body inertial sensing, (2) identify the minimal set of on-body sensor locations to provide high-quality mobility analysis, (3) determine the appropriate algorithms to identify fall prone individuals in controlled in- and out-of-lab data collections to assess the external influences of context and activities, and (4) validate the TEMPO-based data collection and processing algorithms in a naturalistic HFC living environment.

This project enables a new paradigm in elderly patient care to target fall prevention interventions to high fall risk individuals before fall incidents occur, preserving patient's health and quality of life while reducing health care costs. In addition, the above described fundamental scientific objectives apply in the broader application of energy efficient BSNs in a variety of application domains. The education and outreach plans focus on crossing the disciplinary divide between technology and health care, using hands-on public demonstrations, undergraduate laboratory modules, and multi-disciplinary videoconferencing graduate seminar courses to attract and develop leaders who can address the tremendous challenges that face the health care industry in the coming decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed the fundamental scientific issues related to 1) designing and operating wearable wireless inertial sensors for longitudinal, continuous, non-invasive motion capture and 2) developing the algorithms that process the captured data for mobility analysis and fall risk assessment. By achieving these two tightly coupled goals (e.g., battery life is highly dependent on the quality of information the sensing system and data analysis algorithms provide), we provided the foundation for health care workers to identify fall prone individuals as soon as mobility impairments arise so that targeted interventions can be made before fall events occur. The project specifically focused on providing such gait monitoring and fall risk assessment in the patient's natural living environment, specifically long-term health care facilities (HCFs). 

The transdisciplinary research team (which included expertise in gait analysis, body sensor networks, low power radio frequency (RF) circuits, and gerontology) worked together to address the following scientific objectives: 1) Explore on-node signal processing and low power RF transceivers to balance energy consumption and mobility analysis fidelity in wireless on-body inertial sensing. 2) Identify the minimal set of on-body sensor locations to provide high-quality mobility analysis. 3) Determine the appropriate algorithms to identify fall prone individuals (among three groups of participants - healthy young, healthy old, and fall prone elderly) in controlled in- and out-of-lab data collections to assess the external influences of context and activities. 4) Validate the body worn sensor data collection and processing algorithms in a naturalistic HCF living environment.

Highlight contributions from work at UVA include the following:

1) We developed a framework to evaluate the quality of information the body sensor network provides within the context of the target fall risk application. This enables the exploration tradeoffs between energy consumption and the resulting quality of information the system provides when using lossy compression, using resource constrained signal processing, being subjected to noise, dropped packets, and other loss, etc. Understanding the impact of these noise/loss sources is crucial to informing system design and optimization decisions. For example, the wireless communication and networking protocols must be informed by the application-impact of dropped transmission packets and the energy cost of handshaking, node-coordination, packet retransmission, etc. Our results validated the importance of this application-centric framework, showing that relevant application metrics do not correlate well with traditional data quality metrics like mean squared error (MSE).

2) As an extension, the project explored the potential for optimizing the tradeoff between meeting a desired battery lifetime and maximizing system information quality through run-time system adaptation and profile-based predictions of an individual's future activities. A "personal activity profile" describes the expected behavior of an individual and is used to inform the desired battery discharge characteristics over time. This approach was evaluated using inertial data collected from a body sensor platform over several months in a personal activity monitoring application with sensor acquisition duty cycling as the primary system configuration variable. Results showed improvements over statically setting a duty cycle for constant power consumption and deviations from ideally setting the duty cycle based upon a priori knowledge of activities of interest throughout the system lifetime.

3) Gait analysis and fall risk assessment in natural settings require dealing with many real-world deployment issues, including senor noise that arises from mounting errors (from sensor displacement orientation) and looseness of sensors. Despite the success of various activity analysis algorithms to improve system performance, most existing algorithms are limited in one aspect: the sensor signals must exhibit stable and repeatable patterns. In other words, the signal patterns should exhibit similarity for the same motion within a certain tolerance range. However, human factors during the deployment of inertial sensors may cause the signal patterns to become unstable and unrepeatable for the same motion. Therefore, adding the considerations of human factors during the deployment of inertial body sensors should enhance the system performance in real-world deployments. We therefore explored methods for extracting sets of human actions from inertial data at different time scales that are robust against mounting errors and sensor looseness. We ultimately developed a Piecewise Linear Dynamical Model (PLDM) with Motion Stimulus Detection to differentiate at the coarse level between activities like walking, running, and other limb movements, as well as to segment finer parts of actions like walking into heel strike and toe off. This work further explored the challenges of variability in outpatient data collection, including changes in walking surface, walking speed, and sensor orientation. We developed rotation, scale, and offset invariant dynamic time warping (RSOI-DTW), a variant of the well-known dynamic time warping (DTW) algorithm, as a generalization of DTW appropriate for three dimensional inertial data that preserves the salient features of gait cycles required for gait monitoring and ultimately fall risk assessment.
